section.title: net-destroy
section.para: Shuts down a virtual network, releasing any resources in use by it.

entry.para: The name or UUID of the network to be shut down..

formalpara.title: Linux
formalpara.para: If the virtualisation host is running Linux, the name the operating system uses for the network interface can be found using the virsh command.

listitem.para: Look for the name value of the bridge line. virbr100 in this instance:
listitem.screen: virsh # net-dumpxml examplenetwork <network> <name>examplenetwork</name> <uuid>b7005dec-be1a-fe9a-338a-0cb1301dfcfd</uuid> <forward mode='route'/> <bridge name='virbr100' stp='on' delay='0' /> <ip address='10.10.120.1' netmask='255.255.255.0'> </ip> </network>
listitem.para: Using ifconfig, or a similar tool such as ip, the virbr100 interface will be seen on the host when the virtual network is running:
listitem.screen: # ifconfig virbr100 virbr100 Link encap:Ethernet HWaddr D2:43:D9:47:FA:AA inet addr:10.10.120.1 Bcast:10.10.120.255 Mask:255.255.255.0 UP BROADCAST RUNNING MULTICAST MTU:1500 Metric:1 RX packets:0 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0 TX packets:7 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0 collisions:0 txqueuelen:0 RX bytes:0 (0.0 b) TX bytes:1553 (1.5 KiB)
listitem.para: After shutting down a virtual network with the net-destroy command, the Linux OS will no longer show this interface:
listitem.screen: # ifconfig virbr100 virbr100: error fetching interface information: Device not found

example.para: Shuts down the virtual network named "mynetwork".
Shuts down the virtual network that has a UUID of "bfbc4c69-7d6a-cc9a-904c-09910ce179c0".

listitem.para: Starting with a virtual network named examplenetwork, already running on a virtualisation host server:
listitem.screen: virsh # net-list Name State Autostart ----------------------------------------- default active yes examplenetwork active yes
listitem.para: The network is shut down by simply using the net-destroy command on it:
The command now shows it as inactive:
listitem.screen: virsh # net-list --all Name State Autostart ----------------------------------------- default active yes examplenetwork inactive yes

listitem.para: - Creates a running, transient virtual network, using settings from an XML file.
- Displays a list of the virtual networks libvirt is aware of.
- Manually starts a virtual network that isn't running.
